docs.lead_paragraph: The United States Public Health Service, in a new study of infant mortality, says that nine states have particularly serious problems and that the data for the nation as a whole are ''cause for concern.'' Statistics have shown that the rate of decline in the infant mortality rate nationwide has slowed. But the new study showed an increase in the mortality rate of babies after the newborn stage. Furthermore, the report said that if current trends continued, the nation would not reach its 1990 goals for reducing the mortality rate of black babies, increasing prenatal care and reducing the proportion of babies with low weight at birth. The Administration recently rejected a proposal to study whether Federal spending cutbacks have had any effect on infant mortality.

headline.main: 'CAUSE FOR CONCERN' ON INFANT MORTALITY SEEN BY U.S. AGENCY
